awd_titl_txt: RUI/Collaborative Research: MSB-ECA: Mice-o-scapes: Using isotopes to understand the effect of climate and landscape change on small mammal ecology over the past 100 years
awd_abstract_narration:
Climate, vegetation, and land-use change have had a dramatic impact on environments and species ecology across the United States over the past 100 years. Understanding these impacts is necessary for guiding future conservation and management decisions, and for developing indicators to assess ecosystem health. While much work has focused on the response of ecosystems to these changes on local or regional scales, many questions remain as to how climate and landscape changes will affect ecosystems at a continental scale. Small mammals, such as rodents, represent a significant proportion of the mammalian species in North America, and are bellweathers of ecosystem change. Small mammals record many aspects of their diet and environment in their tissues via stable isotopes, but key questions remain about the spatial scale represented by small-mammal isotopes and the aspects of the environment that they record.

This work will fill a major gap in our understanding of the climatic and environmental controls on stable isotopes recorded by small mammals at a continental scale.  Specifically, we will combine biogeochemistry and modeling techniques using modern specimens obtained from the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) combined with historical specimens from natural history museums.  We will determine how the isotopic composition of small mammals varies in relation to continental-scale climate and vegetation gradients and create mice-o-scapes?isotope landscape models predicting the stable isotopic composition of small-mammal hair across the United States. These landscape models will allow us to better understand the spatial scales and environmental variables recorded by small mammals, as well as differences in diet among species. We will then use historical small-mammal specimens obtained from various museum collections to assess how small mammals have responded to environmental change from the late 19th century to the present. We will target four different regions of the United States that have undergone dramatic but different forms of land-use change over the past 100 years, including urbanization, agricultural expansion, deforestation, and grassland-rangeland transition. This project emphasizes the importance of integrating museum collections as archives of ecological change with the NEON network, while helping to establish the careers of the young female research team and increasing research opportunities for underrepresented minorities at a Hispanic-serving institution.

por.por_cntn:
Climate, landscape and land-use change have had a dramatic impact on the environment and ecological dynamics across the United States over the past 100 years, but many questions remain about how these drivers interact. Small mammals are tightly linked with the properties of their local habitats, such as substrate, microclimate, and vegetation. Therefore, small mammals are an important indicator of ecosystem change and record many aspects of their environment in their tissues via stable isotopes. We used the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) coupled with historical museum specimens to compare the isotopic composition (δ13C, δ15N, δ18O) of widespread small mammals to soils, plants, and precipitation collected across space and through time, with a focus on understanding spatial variability and temporal change in the Pacific Northwest and Southern California. We generated large isotopic datasets and built mice-o-scapes – isotope landscape models as recorded by small-mammal hair - to determine the primary climatic and ecological controls on small-mammal isotopic composition today and in the past. We then compared modern isoscape predictions from NEON data and regional-scale changes in small-mammal isotopic composition over the past 100 years under distinct scenarios of land-use and hydrological change to understand the interacting effects of climate and anthropogenetic drivers on ecosystems.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes:

Our work demonstrates that today, human population density is the strongest predictor of δ13C values across the US west coast, implying that vegetation changes due to urbanization are indeed recorded in the isotopic composition of small-mammal hair. Prior to 1935, however, the carbon isotopic composition of small mammals is mainly controlled by climatic variables, with mean annual temperature and vapor pressure deficit having the strongest control on δ13C values.  We also detect a trend of decreasing variability on δ13C values with increasing human population density, suggesting that the diets of small mammals have become more constrained through time. This could be a result of a turnover from agricultural to urban C3-dominated landscapes coupled with the removal of water stress from plants due to irrigation.

δ15N patterns across space are structured by distance from the coast, with high values along sites closest to the coast, reflecting the input of marine N to the N cycle, and high values farthest from the coast, reflecting the increasing influence of aridity on N cycling in desert regions. Precipitation variables coupled with distance to the coast emerge as the most important drivers of δ15N patterns across space and through time. This is important because it illustrates strong climatic and geographical controls on δ15N values in mammals; previously, many have assumed trophic level to be the primary influence on mammalian δ15N values. In addition to the range of δ13C values contracting through time, there also appears to be a similar contraction in δ15N values as well, perhaps due to increasing atmospheric deposition of N from vehicle exhaust or fertilizer derived from the Haber-Bosch process.

Finally, analyses of δ18O and δ2H values in the Pacific Northwest (PNW) and Southern California mice reveal that the meteoric water line has shifted over the last century in both regions. In the PNW, the relationship has been lost, indicating a decoupling of processes influencing oxygen and hydrogen isotopic composition. In Southern California, however, the relationship has significantly shifted in slope and intercept, indicating less arid conditions over time. This shift is not reflected in the climate data themselves, thus can likely be attributed to increased irrigation into the region, which influences the isotopic composition of the vegetation consumed by small mammals at the regional scale. Our results suggest that mice are sensitive enough environmental data recorders to capture changes in water sources through time.

Broader Impact Outcomes:

Our study has provided numerous benefits to society beyond the enhanced data infrastructure of the NEON network, contributions of predictive isoscapes to the literature, and knowledge about biotic response to environmental change. We also provided scientific and professional training to two postdoctoral researchers, three graduate students, and seven undergraduate students (trained in field and/or lab techniques). The two postdocs and four of the undergraduate students and two of the graduate students are female, four are from underrepresented groups in STEM, and three are non-traditional. Five of these undergraduate students were also mentored through independent research projects and presented their findings at either a University-based or local/national scientific conference. Training in the communication of science is critical for many career paths in research, teaching, and conservation. To date, one Master’s thesis has been completed and one is underway, five undergraduate honors theses have been completed, and ten peer-reviewed scientific publications are currently in preparation from this work.
